body.p: DECAY OF SOLUTIONS OF SOME NONLINEAR EQUATIONS
MOHAMMED AASSILA

Abstract: For a class of scalar partial differential equations that incorporate convection, diffusion, and possibly dispersion in one space and one time dimension, the stability of solutions is investigated.
1.Introduction
The topic of this paper is the class of equations

m:math.alttext: u_{t}-\alpha u_{xx}+\beta u_{xxx}+\gamma u_{xxxxt}+(g(u))_{x}=0,\ x\in\mathbb{% R},\ t>0

m:semantics.m:annotation: u_{t}-\alpha u_{xx}+\beta u_{xxx}+\gamma u_{xxxxt}+(g(u))_{x}=0,\ x\in\mathbb{% R},\ t>0

body.p: where subscripts denote partial derivatives. The case ğ‘”ğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢22gâ¢(u)=u22g(u)=\displaystyle\frac{u^{2}}{2} and ğ›¾0Î³=0\gamma=0 is typical and has received much attention. If formulae-sequenceğ›¼0ğ›½0Î±>0,Î²=0\alpha>0,\beta=0, this is known as Burgers equation. If formulae-sequenceğ›¼0ğ›½0Î±=0,Î²>0\alpha=0,\beta>0, this is essentially the Korteweg-de-Vries equation. The case formulae-sequenceğ›¼0ğ›½0Î±>0,Î²>0\alpha>0,\beta>0 is thus refereed to as KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V}-Burgers equation; it also has been studied extensively as has been the case of general ğ‘”gg. The case ğ‘”ğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢ğ‘1ğ‘1gâ¢(u)=up+1p+1g(u)=\displaystyle\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1} and formulae-sequenceğ›¾1ğ›½0Î³=1,Î²=0\gamma=1,\beta=0 where ğ‘1pâ‰¥1p\geq 1 is an integer is refereed to as the Rosenau-Burgers equation. Indeed, if ğ›¼0Î±=0\alpha=0 then we have the Rosenau equation proposed by Rosenau 8 for treating the dynamics of dense discrette systems in order to overcome the shortenings by the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V} equation, since the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V} equation describes unidimensional propagation of waves, but wave-wave and wave-wall interactions cannot be treated by it. Such a model were studied by Park 9 and Chung and Ha 3 for the global existence of the solution to the IBVP. Equation (1.1) with formulae-sequenceğ›¼0formulae-sequenceğ›¾1ğ›½0Î±>0,Î³=1,Î²=0\alpha>0,\gamma=1,\beta=0 is called the Rosenau- Burgers equation and somehow corresponds to the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V}-Burgers equation and the BenjaBonaBenjaâ¢min-Bona\displaystyle\mathrm{B}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{n}\mathrm{j}\mathrm{a}\min-\mathrm{B}% \mathrm{o}\mathrm{n}\mathrm{a}-Mahoney-Burgers equation, but it is given neither by Rosenau nor by Burgers. The Rosenau equation with the dissipative term ğ›¼subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¥-Î±â¢uxâ¢x-\alpha u_{xx}, or say, the Rosenau-Burgers equation arises in some natural phenomena as for example, in bore propagation and in water waves.
In section 2 of this paper, we study the problem (1.1) with formulae-sequenceğ›½1ğ›¾0Î²=1,Î³=0\beta=1,\gamma=0:

where ğ›¼0Î±>0\alpha>0 and ğ‘”gg is a superscriptğ¶2C2C^{2}-class function. We give a general criterion for the existence of traveling wave solutions of the form ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-Ï•ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¡uâ¢(x,t)=Ï•â¢(x-câ¢t)u(x,\ t)=\phi(x-ct) .
In section 3, we study the asymptotic behaviour of the solution for the Rosenau- Burgers equation (problem (1.1) with formulae-sequenceğ›½0ğ›¾1Î²=0,Î³=1\beta=0,\gamma=1):
where ğ›¼0Î±>0\alpha>0 and ğ‘1pâ‰¥1p\geq 1 is an integer.
The problem (E2) was studied by Mei 7. He proved that if subscriptâ„subscriptğ‘¢0ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥0âˆ«â„u0â¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘xâ‰ 0\int_{\mathbb{R}}u_{0}(x)dx\neq 0 then

subscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘¡superscriptğ¿2ğ‘superscript1ğ‘¡4âˆ¥uâ¢(t)âˆ¥L2â‰¤c(1+t)4\displaystyle\|u(t)\|_{L^{2}}\leq\frac{c}{(1+t)^{4}} and formulae-sequencesubscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘1ğ‘¡for-allğ‘¡0âˆ¥uâ¢(t)âˆ¥âˆâ‰¤c1+t,âˆ€tâ‰¥0\displaystyle\|u(t)\|_{\infty}\leq\frac{c}{\sqrt{1+t}},\forall t\geq 0
And, if subscriptâ„subscriptğ‘¢0ğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¥0âˆ«â„u0â¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x=0\int_{\mathbb{R}}u_{0}(x)dx=0, then

subscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘¡superscriptğ¿2ğ‘superscript1ğ‘¡34âˆ¥uâ¢(t)âˆ¥L2â‰¤c(1+t)3/4\|u(t)\|_{L^{2}}\leq\frac{c}{(1+t)^{3/4}} and formulae-sequencesubscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ‘1ğ‘¡for-allğ‘¡0âˆ¥uâ¢(t)âˆ¥âˆâ‰¤c1+t,âˆ€tâ‰¥0\|u(t)\|_{\infty}\leq\frac{c}{1+t},\forall t\geq 0

Hence, it is proved in 7 that 00 is the asymptotic state of the solution ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¡uâ¢(x,t)u(x,\ t) for the Rosenau-Burgers equation. In this paper, we prove that the solution of the nonlinear parabolic equation subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ›¼subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¢ğ‘1ğ‘1ğ‘¥0ut-Î±â¢uxâ¢x+(up+1p+1)x=0u_{t}-\displaystyle\alpha u_{xx}+(\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1})_{x}=0 is a better asymptotic proflle for the Rosenau-Burgers equation. Furthermore, we prove that the convergence to this asymptotic proflle is faster than the convergence to 00 proved in 7.
Before ending this section, we state and prove a general technical lemma which will be needed later.
Lemma 1.1.

2.Existence of traveling wave solutions
Consider the equation
where ğ›¼0Î±>0\alpha>0 and ğ‘”gg is a superscriptğ¶2C2C^{2}-class function.

Under certain conditions, the equation admits monotone traveling wave solu- tions ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-Ï•ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¡uâ¢(x,t)=Ï•â¢(x-câ¢t)u(x,\ t)=\phi(x-ct) with speed ğ‘cc that connect the end states subscriptitalic-Ï•plus-or-minussubscriptâ†’ğ‘Ÿplus-or-minusitalic-Ï•ğ‘ŸÏ•Â±=limrâ†’Â±âˆâ¡Ï•â¢(r)\displaystyle\phi_{\pm}=\lim_{r\rightarrow\pm\infty}\phi(r) . Such a wave proflle must satisfy the third order ordinary difierential equation

An example is ğ‘”ğ‘¥2ğ‘¥ğ‘¥1ğ‘ğ‘¥gâ¢(x)=2â¢xâ¢(x-1)â¢(b-x)g(x)=2x(x-1)(b-x) with ğ‘2bâ‰¥2b\geq 2, which has the wave profile italic-Ï•ğ‘¥11superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥Ï•â¢(x)=11+ex\displaystyle\phi(x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{x}} for the parameter ğ›¼2ğ‘1Î±=2â¢b-1\alpha=2b-1 and the speed ğ‘0c=0c=0. General profiles (non necessarily monotone) have been constructed in 15. It is known that monotone proflles exist for ğ‘”ğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢ğ‘1ğ‘1gâ¢(u)=up+1p+1g(u)=\displaystyle\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1} and ğ›¼2ğ‘ğ‘Î±â‰¥2â¢pâ¢c\alpha\geq 2\sqrt{pc}. More generally, we have the following criterion:
Theorem 2.1. Letğ‘”superscriptğ¶2gâˆˆC2g\in C^{2}be a strictly convex function. A monotone wave profileitalic-Ï•Ï•\phiforğ¸ğ‘™(Eâ¢l)(El)exists if only if:
The proflle must therefore be monotonically decreasingProof:

Then, ğ‘“ff is concave, and ğ›¼superscriptğœ“â€²superscriptğœ“â€²â€²ğ‘“ğœ“-Î±â¢Ïˆâ€²-Ïˆâ€²â€²=fâ¢(Ïˆ)-\alpha\psi^{{}^{\prime}}-\psi^{{}^{\prime\prime}}=f(\psi) which is the equation for a wave profile ğœ“Ïˆ\psi of the Fisher-Kolmogorov-Petrovskii-Piskunov (F-KPP) equation subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘£vt-vxâ¢x=fâ¢(v)v_{t}-v_{xx}=f(v) that travels to the right with speed ğ›¼Î±\alpha and has limits formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ“subscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptğœ“0Ïˆ-=Ï•--Ï•+,Ïˆ+=0\psi_{-}=\phi_{-}-\phi_{+},\psi_{+}=0.

Thanks to 4, we know that such a monotone wave profile for concave ğ‘“ff exists if and only if ğ›¼2superscriptğ‘“â€²02superscriptğ‘”â€²subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘Î±â‰¥2â¢fâ€²â¢(0)=2â¢gâ€²â¢(Ï•-)-c\alpha\geq 2\sqrt{f^{{}^{\prime}}(0)}=2\sqrt{g^{{}^{\prime}}(\phi_{-})-c}. In this case, subscriptğœ“subscriptğœ“Ïˆ->Ïˆ+\psi_{-}>\psi_{+} and therefore subscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptitalic-Ï•Ï•->Ï•+\phi_{-}>\phi_{+}, since ğ‘“ff is positive between subscriptğœ“Ïˆ-\psi_{-} and subscriptğœ“Ïˆ+\psi_{+}. Thus (2.2)-(2.3) are true.

Define ğ‘“ff as in (2.4), then by known results about the F-KPP equation, there exists a unique decreasing wave profile ğœ“Ïˆ\psi with ğœ“0subscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptitalic-Ï•2Ïˆâ¢(0)=Ï•--Ï•+2\psi(0)=\frac{\phi_{-}-\phi_{+}}{2} that moves to the right with speed ğ›¼Î±\alpha. Then, italic-Ï•ğ‘§subscriptitalic-Ï•ğœ“ğ‘§Ï•â¢(z)=Ï•--Ïˆâ¢(-z)\phi(z)=\phi_{-}-\psi(-z) is a monotone wave profile for (E1) with italic-Ï•plus-or-minussubscriptitalic-Ï•plus-or-minusÏ•â¢(Â±âˆ)=Ï•Â±\phi(\pm\infty)=\phi_{\pm}
3.Asymptotic proflle of Rosenau-Burgers equation

Consider the Rosenau-Burgers equation in the form casessubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¡ğ›¼subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¢ğ‘1ğ‘1ğ‘¥0formulae-sequenceğ‘¥â„ğ‘¡0ğ‘¢ğ‘¥Osubscriptğ‘¢0ğ‘¥â†’0asğ‘¥â†’plus-or-minusmissing-subexpression{ut-Î±â¢uxâ¢x+uxâ¢xâ¢xâ¢xâ¢t+(up+1p+1)x=0,xâˆˆâ„,t>0,uâ¢(x,O)=u0â¢(x)â†’0â¢asâ¢xâ†’Â±âˆ,\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}u_{t}-\alpha u_{xx}+u_{xxxxt}+(\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1})_% {x}=0,&x\in\mathbb{R},\ t>0,\\ u(x,\ \mathrm{O})=u_{0}(x)\rightarrow 0\ \mathrm{a}\mathrm{s}\ x\rightarrow\pm% \infty,&\end{array}\right.
where ğ›¼Î±\alpha is any given constant, ğ‘1pâ‰¥1p\geq 1 is integer.

Proof of Theorem 3.1: Rewriting (3.18) in the form ğ‘¤ğ‘†ğ‘¤w=Sâ¢ww=Sw, we need to prove that there exists a positive constant subscriptğ›¿1Î´1\delta_{1} such that the operator ğ‘†SS is a contraction mapping from superscriptsubscriptğ‘†superscriptğ‘1ğ›¿Sp1Î´S_{p^{1}}^{\delta} into superscriptsubscriptğ‘†superscriptğ‘1ğ›¿Sp1Î´.S_{p^{1}}^{\delta}.

We claim that ğ‘†SS maps superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ›¿SpÎ´S_{p}^{\delta} into itself. Indeed, for any subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ›¿w1â¢(x,t)âˆˆSpÎ´w_{1}(x,\ t)\in S_{p}^{\delta} and denoting ğ‘¤ğ‘†subscriptğ‘¤1w=Sâ¢w1w=Sw_{1} we will prove that ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ›¿wâˆˆSpÎ´w\in S_{p}^{\delta} for some small ğ›¿0Î´>0\delta>0. Thanks to lemma 3.6, for any positive integer ğ‘pp there exists a constant subscriptğ‘1c1c_{1} such that

Let ğ‘›2superscript2ğ‘11subscriptğ‘1n=maxâ¡{2+2p+1,1c1}n=\displaystyle\max\{2+2^{p+1},\displaystyle\frac{1}{c_{1}}\}, and choose subscriptğ›¿21ğ‘›subscriptğ‘1Î´2â‰¤1nâ¢c1\displaystyle\delta_{2}\leq\frac{1}{nc_{1}}, then for formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£0superscriptğ‘Š31subscriptğ›¿2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘1ğ›¼subscriptğ›¿2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘1âˆ¥v0âˆ¥W3,1â‰¤Î´2nâ¢c1,Î±â‰¤Î´2nâ¢c1\displaystyle\|v_{0}\|_{W^{3,1}}\leq\frac{\delta_{2}}{nc_{1}},\displaystyle% \alpha\leq\frac{\delta_{2}}{nc_{1}} and ğ›¿subscriptğ›¿2Î´<Î´2\delta<\delta_{2} we have
